A B S T R A C T

Rooted cuttings from two carnation (
Dianthus caryophyllus
L.) cultivars showing contrasting responses to the vascular wilt caused by
Fusarium oxysporum
f. sp. dianthi ( Fod ) were inoculated with this phytopathogen, and some of the biochemical responses associated with flavonoid biosynthesis were investigated in the roots. The resistant cultivar (‘
Golem
’) showed a significant increase in the levels of phenolic and flavonoid compounds at 48–96 h post-inoculation (hpi) ( α = 0.05 ). LC-MS-based analysis indicated that the flavonoids mainly included flavanol-type glycosides, especially quercetin and kaempferol aglycones. Quantification of the mRNA levels of genes encoding CHS ( Chalcone Synthase ), CHI ( Chalcone Isomerase ), FLS ( Flavonol Synthase ), and the transcription factor MYB11 by using reverse transcription quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) indicated that the resistant cultivar exhibited higher expression levels of these genes and, therefore, showed more flavonoid accumulation at 96 hpi. The differences in the temporal regulation of the assessed variables during infection support the idea that the early expression of enzymes of the flavonoid biosynthesis pathway in carnation roots is linked to a resistance response to the hemibiotrophic pathogen Fod race 2. The present experimental approach is the first report describing the molecular mechanisms underlying flavonoid biosynthesis in carnation roots during their interaction with Fod .

sec.title: 2. Results and discussion
sec.p: The effects of Fod infection on flavonoid biosynthesis in carnation were investigated under a three-phase study, whose workflow is outlined in Fig. 1 . The study phases consisted of several experimental and analytical steps. Phase 1 involved an assessment of the phenotypic responses of two carnation cultivars to Fod infection on the basis of their differential responses against this pathogen in the field in order to classify them into resistant and susceptible cultivars. Once these cultivar-dependent responses were verified, phase II was oriented to design an in vivo Fod -inoculation assay to evaluate the early responses of these carnation cultivars by sampling roots at different post-inoculation times. In phase III, the collected roots (per time, cultivar and Fod -inoculated or non-inoculated condition) were extracted and the chemical and transcriptional changes caused by Fod presence were finally examined.

sec.p: 2.1. Differential Fod resistance levels of the carnation cultivars used in the in vivo assay

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
The differential pathogen responses of the two carnation cultivars (‘
Golem
’ and ‘ Mizuki ’) were examined in a 7-week post-inoculation in vivo assay. Plants of these cultivars were rigorously scrutinized each week during the experiment and, if symptoms of vascular wilting were detected, these plants were registered at those time points and the severity index (SI) was calculated (see Experimental section). Disease evolution (expressed as SI over time) exhibited differences among cultivars and between inoculated and control plants ( Fig. 2 ). ‘ Mizuki ’ began to show symptoms of the disease at the fourth week (SI = 0.1), while ‘
Golem
’ showed symptoms from the sixth week, indicating differences in the disease progression in these cultivars. Finally, ‘ Mizuki ’ reached an SI value of 0.7 at the seventh week, which was significantly higher (
P < 0.05
) than that of ‘
Golem
’ (SI = 0.3). The symptoms of the carnation cultivar ‘
Golem
’ are consistent with the previously reported quantitative Fod resistance trait, wherein some symptoms of wilting may appear under a high inoculum pressure (
;
;
). Visual analysis of cross-sections of the stems of the inoculated carnation plants shows degradation of the vascular tissue in ‘ Mizuki ’, and an evident browning process in the vascular xylematic tissues of ‘
Golem
’, as reported previously in resistant genotypes (
). The contrasting phenotypic responses of these two carnation cultivars against Fod was confirmed from this in vivo experiment and comparable to the field observations. Therefore, under these experimental conditions, these cultivars were classified as ‘
Golem
’ resistant cultivar (GRC) and ‘ Mizuki ’ susceptible cultivar (MSC). These cultivars were then used in the subsequent in vivo assays to evaluate the early-stage chemical and transcriptional changes.

sec.title: 2.2. Chemical variations in carnation roots during the Fod-inoculation in vivo assay
sec.p: Both carnation cultivars with contrasting responses to Fod infection (i.e., GRC and MSC ) were employed in a subsequent 96-h Fod -inoculation in vivo assay to explore the variations of the phenolic and flavonoid contents as well as the liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry (LC-MS)-derived flavonoid profiles of carnation roots at the early phase in response to Fod presence, according to our workflow ( Fig. 1 ).

sec.title: 2.3. Variations in the transcript levels of genes encoding flavonoid biosynthesis enzymes in carnation roots during the Fod-inoculation in vivo assay
sec.p:
The transcript levels of genes encoding flavonoid biosynthesis enzymes were evaluated by RT-qPCR during the 96-h in vivo Fod -inoculation assay. In this study, inoculation with the pathogen generated a significant increase in mRNA levels of the putative genes encoding CHS, CHI, and FLS enzymes and the TF cMYB ( Fig. 7 ). At the constitutive level (0 hpi), no significant differences were observed in the transcription of the chs and chi genes for two carnation cultivars ( GRC and MSC ) and, in general, chi showed a similar profile to that observed for chs ( Fig. 7a and b ). These results do not completely coincide with the findings reported by
, who showed that resistant carnation cultivars have higher transcriptional levels than susceptible cultivars. However, the two sets of results cannot be directly compared because the strategy for gene expression quantification differed across the studies, with the previous study using the absolute quantification expressed as transcript copies of each gene by the total RNA extracted. Transcript levels of chs in roots during the pathogen infection did not exhibit differences between the treatments at 12 and 24 hpi, but a significant mRNA level increase at 48 hpi was observed in both cultivars, with the increase being higher in the resistant cultivar ( Fig. 7a ). Additionally, significant differences were only observed in the inoculated roots of GRC at 96 hpi. For the transcript levels of the chi gene, a significant increase in the resistant genotype GRC at 24 and 48 hpi was caused by pathogen inoculation ( Fig. 7b ). The results for the transcriptional levels of these genes ( chs and chi ) at 24 and 48 hpi can be related to the accumulation of flavonoids at 96 hpi for this resistant cultivar ( Figs. 5–6 ). Therefore, the transcriptional increase of the chs and chi genes may be a response possibly associated with pathogen resistance.
TFC: total flavonoid content, CHS: chalcone synthase, CHI: chalcone isomerase, FLS: flavonol synthase, MYB: transcription factor.

sec.title: 3. Concluding remarks
sec.p:
Since phenylpropanoid-derived specialized metabolites are valuable components in plant defense responses, flavonoid-based discrimination of resistant and susceptible carnation cultivars is a favorable strategy to identify these resistance-related biochemical and molecular traits. Thus, to expand the current understanding of the mechanisms underlying the inherent resistance and induced response against vascular wilting, the present study determined the early variations in the metabolite and transcriptional levels in carnation roots in response to Fod . The disease evolved faster in the susceptible variety (‘ Mizuki ’, MSC ) than in the resistant variety (‘
Golem
’, GRC ), while the accumulation of certain flavonol acylglycosides (e.g., kaempferol 3- O -(acetyl-rhamnosyl)- diglucoside ( 6 ) and kaempferol 3- O -(sinapoyl-glucosyl)-glucoside ( 11 )) in GRC was faster (48 hpi) to those in MSC (at 96 hpi), suggesting that these compounds play a defensive role (e.g., phytoanticipins, phytoalexins and/or antioxidants) against Fod . In addition, both cultivars exhibited a pathogen presence-dependent early response (12–96 hpi) based on an increase in transcriptional levels of flavonoid biosynthesis pathway-related enzymes, but GRC showed the highest expression levels of such genes faster (i.e., cmyb11 at 12 hpi, chi and chs genes at 24 hpi, and fls at 48 hpi) to promote a temporally controlled polygenic response against Fod that was oriented to favor a particular accumulation of acylglycosylated kaempferol-like flavonols at 96 hpi. However, antifungal and antioxidant evaluation and functional assays using carnation mutants will be useful to demonstrate the role of each component in this molecular and biochemical model. Our findings using the present combined metabolomics- and transcriptional-based approach confirmed that flavonoid biosynthesis is a part of the complex response related to carnation resistance to the vascular wilting caused by Fod . This constitutes valuable background information for the selection of plants for carnation breeding based on differences in flavonoids and genes conferring disease resistance.

sec.title: 4.1. Biological samples
sec.p:
Rooted cuttings (3-week rooting) from two commercial cultivars (‘
Golem
’ resistant ( GRC ) and ‘ Mizuki ’ susceptible (MCS)) of
Dianthus caryophyllus
L. ( Caryophyllaceae ) were used. These carnation plants were grown in Colombia and were supplied by the company Florval SAS campus QFC (Bogota´Plateu, Colombia ).
Fusarium oxysporum
f. sp dianthi ( Fod ) race 2 was isolated from susceptible plants with typical symptoms of vascular wilt. This fungal isolate was maintained in a solid potato dextrose agar (PDA) medium. The typical morphology of conidia was observed through microscopy, and the species and race were verified through molecular tools described below (Abd-elsalam et al., 2003;
). Inoculum was prepared in previously sterilized Czapek-Dox broth by stirring for 7 days at 25 ◦ C. Medium was diluted with sterile water to obtain a suspension with a final concentration of 1.0 × 10 6 conidia/mL.

Hence, 25 plants of each treatment were maintained until 7 weeks post-inoculation and disease incidence were evaluated as the severity index ( SI ) based on the 0–4 scale previously proposed (
) as follows: 0 = no symptomatic plant, 1 = plant with 1/3 of symptoms, 2 = plant with 2/3 of symptoms, 3 = whole plant with symptoms, 4 = plant death. SI (%) = ([Σ(Class frequency × score of rating class)]/(Total number of observations) × (maximal score of rating class)) × 100, where ‘score of rating class’ is related to the disease level based on the proposed scale, ‘class frequency’ is the number of plants showing that score, ‘total number of observations’ is the total number of plants within the experiment, and the ‘maximal score of rating class’ is 4.

sec.title: 4.3. Phenolic total extraction
sec.p:
Polar metabolites from controls and inoculated carnation roots were extracted from 200 mg of roots using 1 mL of 80% (v/v) methanol. The samples were crushed, sonicated for 15 min (42 Hz and 100 W) and centrifuged (12,000× g , 15 min). The supernatants were transferred to eppendorf tubes and stored in the dark at 20 ◦ C for subsequent analysis (
).

4.3.2. Determination of flavonoid content
sec.p:
Flavonoid content was determined using the aluminum chloride method (
). Each reaction mixture contained carnation roots extract (100 μL), 5% NaNO 2 (30 μL) and deionized water (100 μL). After 5 min, 10% AlCl 3 (60 μL) was added, and after additional 6 min at room temperature, 2 M NaOH (100 μL) was also added. Absorbance was measured at 510 nm in a Varioskan™ LUX plate reader. Absorbance units were compared to a calibration curve previously prepared using samples containing 0, 5, 10, 20, 40, 60 ppm of catechin (Sigma). TFC values were expressed as microgram of catechin equivalents per gram of fresh tissue.

sec.title: 4.4. Reverse phase ultra-high performance liquid chromatography coupled to diode array detector and mass spectrometry (RP-UHPLC-PDA-MS) analyses
sec.p: RP-UHPLC-PDA-MS analyses were performed on an Ultra-Fast Liquid Chromatographic (UFLC) Prominence system (Shimadzu, Columbia, MD, USA ) equipped with a photodiode array detector (SPD-M20A) and coupled to a LCMS2020 mass spectrometer with quadrupole analyzer and electrospray ionization (ESI). Chromatographic separation was carried out on a C18 Kinetex® 250 × 4.60 × 2.2 μm column. Elution was conducted with a mobile phase consisting of 0.1% HCOOH in H 20 (solvent A) and 0.1% HCOOH in acetonitrile (Solvent B), which was pumped at a 0.7 mL/min flow rate and the oven temperature was set at 35 ◦ C. Gradient program was set as follows: 0% B (0–3 min), 0%–15% B (4–29 min), 15%–30% B (29–48 min), 30%–100% (48–65 min). Analysis was monitored at 330 nm . ESI was operated simultaneously in positive and negative ion modes (scan 100–2000 m /z), desolvation line temperature at 250 ◦ C, nitrogen as nebulizer gas at 1.5 L/min, drying gas at 15 L/min, and detector voltage at 1.4 kV. Additionally, RP-UHPLCESI-HRMS data were also performed on a UFLC Prominence system coupled to a Bruker MicrOToF-Q II consisting of a Quadrupole-Time of Flight (QToF) analyzer and ESI. Identical chromatographic parameters above mentioned were used. ESI was operated in negative ion mode (scan 100–1500 m /z), capillary voltage at 4.5 kV, desolvation line temperature at 400 ◦ C, nitrogen as nebulizer gas at 4 Bar, drying gas at 8 L/min, quadrupole and collision energy at 7 and 20 eV, respectively.
